direction.raw_text: - SAN FRANCISCO - DAY It is mid-afternoon, and there is a tempo and pace to the people walking, the doorman HOOTING for taxicabs, the policemen directing traffic.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the crowd of pedestrians, approaching Davidson's Pet Shop. She is a young woman in her mid-twenties, sleekly groomed, exquisitely dressed, though hatless. She walks with the quick sureness of the city dweller, a purposefulness in her stride, a mischievous grin on her face. She continues toward the front door of a pet shop and enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melanie opens the door and comes through, still looking back toward the street and skywards. The proprietor, a MRS. MacGRUDER, comes toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Mrs. MacGruder, have you ever seen so many gulls?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Miss Daniels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you suppose it is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. MacGruder takes a look out at the sky. A puppy is BARKING, o.s.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There must be a storm at sea. That can drive them inland, you know. They are climbing the short flight of steps into the bird department now. The BARKING of the dog SEGUES into the clamor of innumerable birds, TWEETING, TWITTERING, CAWING as Melanie and Mrs. MacGruder go to the counter at the far end.  There is a circular cage in the center of the room, and the walls are lined with wire-mesh cages and smaller wooden cages so that the effect is one of being surrounded by birds, contained birds to be sure. The birds are quite beautiful, mostly exotic birds, small splashes of color behind the wire-mesh cages, larger bursts of brilliant hue on the parrots and parakeets in the bigger cages. As they walk:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was hoping you'd be a little late, Miss Daniels. (apologetically) You see, he hasn't arrived yet.

direction.raw_text: You said three o'clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Oh, I know. (she is more distressed now) I've been calling all morning. Oh, you have no idea. Miss Daniels, they're so difficult to get, really they are. We get them from India, you know, when they're just little chicks, and then we have to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, this one won't be a chick, will he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly not. Oh, no. Certainly not. This will be a full grown myna bird. Full grown.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, yes, he'll talk. Well, no, no. You'll have to teach him to talk.

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (pause) Oh my, I suppose I should call them again. They said three o'clock. (pause) Maybe it's the traffic. I'll call. Would you mind waiting?

direction.raw_text: I think maybe you'd better deliver him. Let me give you my address. (she begins taking off her gloves)

direction.raw_text: Oh. Oh, well, all right. As Melanie starts writing:

direction.raw_text: I'm sure they're on the way, though. Could I just call?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, all right, but... She scurries out behind the counter and out of sight.  Melanie finishes writing her address and stands impatiently by the counter. She taps her teeth with the pencil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, this is Betty MacGruder at Davidson's. (pause; accusingly) It's past three, you know. (pause) Well, how long do you think...? All right, would you check it please? Yes, I'll wait. Melanie sighs. Leaving her gloves and purse on the counter, she begins wandering around the shop, still tapping her lips with the pencil. There is no menace in the birds surrounding her. They are active and beautiful as they dart behind the bars and mesh of their cages. Off screen, the puppy begins BARKING again as the front door opens. Melanie looks up.

direction.raw_text: as he closes the entrance door behind him and starts up the steps to the bird department. He is a handsome man, about twenty-nine or thirty, well-dressed, and carrying a felt hat.

direction.raw_text: That case, I tell you what you do. You go straight through town 'til you see a little hotel on your left there. Not the motel, that's the other end of town. This is the hotel. Now you take a right turn there, you got that?

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Near the top of the hill, you'll see the school and right behind it, the church. You head for the school. Now just past the school, you'll see a little house with a red mail box. That's where Annie Hayworth lives, she's the school teacher. You ask her about the little Brenner girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yep. (pause) Could save yourself a lot of trouble. Her name's Alice for sure.

direction.raw_text: Can I have the boat in about twenty minutes? The Clerk nods.

direction.raw_text: It's nothing.

direction.raw_text: passing the mail box and going up the walk to the front door. The house is a two-story frame with steps leading to the front door. There are white curtains in every window of the house, and a sign in the window to the left of the doorway advises, ROOM TO LET. Melanie rings the doorbell.

direction.raw_text: waiting. She RINGS the bell again:

direction.raw_text: Yes? Who is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me!

direction.raw_text: Who's me?

direction.raw_text: walking along the porch of the house. The walk in front of the house is lined with beautifully planted and cared-for flowers. ANNIE HAYWORTH comes round from the back of the house as Melanie reaches the corner. She is a woman of thirty- two, tall, big-boned, with a strong beautiful face.  Her hair is disarrayed at the moment, and she is dressed for the garden, wearing slacks and a loose-fitting sweater, and earth- stained gloves. But there is something about her, a feeling of expansive comfort, rather than sloppiness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Hayworth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Melanie Daniels. I'm sorry to bother you, but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is puzzled by Melanie who, exquisitely dressed and groomed, seems singularly out of place in Bodega Bay. She studies her openly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man at the post office sent me. He said you'd know the name of the little Brenner girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cathy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The one who lives in the white house across the bay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's the one. Cathy Brenner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They seemed sure it was either Alice or Lois.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is why the mail in this town never gets delivered to the right place. (She takes out package of cigarettes, offers one to Melanie) Did you want to see Cathy about something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: taking cigarette, hesitating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... not exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: studying her, thinking she understands.

direction.raw_text: Are you a friend of Mitch's?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is an awkwardness here. Annie wants to know more. She puffs on the cigarette, smiles, tries a friendly approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been wanting a cigarette for the past twenty minutes, but I couldn't convince myself to stop. This 'tilling of the soil' can get a little compulsive, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a lovely garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. It gives me something to do with my spare time. (pause) There's a lot of spare time in Bodega Bay. (another pause) Did you plan on staying long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Just a few hours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're leaving after you see Cathy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... something like that. (pause) I'm sorry. I don't mean to sound so mysterious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, it's none of my business. There is a pause. Melanie, by her silence, affirms that it is none of Annie's business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd better get on my way. Thank you very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. They begin walking toward the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you drive up from San Francisco?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.

direction.raw_text: It's a nice drive. (pause) Is that where you met Mitch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess that's where everyone meets him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as she gets in behind the wheel. Annie's remark is not lost on her, and a quick look of sudden understanding crosses her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you sound a bit mysterious, Miss Hayworth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Annie leans over the seat.

direction.raw_text: Do I? (she shakes her head, smiles wistfully) No, I'm an open book, I'm afraid. (pause) Or maybe a closed one. (she smiles again, sees the lovebirds) Pretty. What are they?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lovebirds. Taking this as a further indication of Melanie's relationship with Mitch:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mmm. (pause) Well, good luck, Miss Daniels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. She nods pleasantly, starts the car, pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watching the car, a look of sad resignation on her face.

direction.raw_text: coming out of Brinkmeyer's General Store, carrying a small paper bag, walking toward her car out front. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her as she gets in. She opens her purse and reaches in for the paper bag.

direction.raw_text: reaching into her purse again for a fountain pen. She unscrews the cap, braces the card on her closed purse.

direction.raw_text: Happy Birthday, the usual rhyming sentiments. The pen writes: To Cathy

direction.raw_text: crossing the highway down into the parking area behind the Tides, close to the docks.

direction.raw_text: She gets out of the car and walks onto one of the docks, the bird cage in her hand. Melanie approaches a waiting fisherman. She asks for her boat. The fisherman nods. He leads her to the dock and the waiting boat.  She gets into the outboard motorboat, the fisherman helping her. He hands down the lovebirds in their cage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pulling away from the dock, heading across the bay.

direction.raw_text: and the wide expanse of the bay, as it heads on a direct course for the house on the other side.

direction.raw_text: coming head-on toward CAMERA, Melanie at the tiller. She cuts the motor. The motor drifts to a stop. The bay is silent except for the cry of the gulls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MELANIE'S P.O.V. There is not a sign of activity as the boat drifts just a little closer. As Melanie watches, the front door opens and a woman comes out, walks to a red pickup truck, starts the engine. A little girl comes out of the house, goes to the truck, gets in. The woman shouts something to a man -- Mitch Brenner, probably, though it is difficult to tell from this distance -- and he comes over to the truck. The truck grinds into gear, goes around the turnabout, and heads down the road away from the farm, a huge cloud of dust behind it. The farm is still again. Mitch stands looking after the truck for a moment, and then begins walking up toward the barn in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watching, biting her lip.

FULL SHOT - CAMERA GETTING NEAR THE HOUSE AND BARN WAIST SHOT - MELANIE crossing the lawn, the CAMERA RETREATING in front of her.

direction.raw_text: Come on, we'd better go up to the restaurant. They walk quickly up the slope to the Tides, establishing gas station across the road, the collection of stores opposite, the cars pulling in and out. Mitch opens the door for her, and they ENTER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a small neighborhood restaurant, with the feeling of a local hangout. There are fishermen lounging at the bar, and a teenage boy playing one of the pinball machines. Two ladies in housedresses, with their hair in curlers, are sitting at one of the booths, having coffee. The rear wall of the restaurant is almost all window, looking out over the bay and the parking area below. A television set over the bar is going. The shots and horsehoof beats of an old Western movie should be HEARD muted throughout following.  DEKE CARTER, who owns the restaurant with his wife, alternates his attention between serving his customers and watching the Western. He looks up immediately when Mitch and Melanie ENTER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mitch and Melanie coming over to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Deke, have you got a first aid kit back there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Young woman cut herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall I call the doctor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think it's that serious. You want to sit up here? Melanie climbs onto the stool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cut yourself outside, Miss?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop worrying, Deke. She was in a boat. He is rummaging around in the kit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had a man trip and fall in the parking lot once, sued me before I could bat an eyelash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think Miss Daniels is going to sue anybody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you're the lawyer. (goes to other end of bar)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that?

direction.raw_text: Just some peroxide. I want to clean out the cut. He pours peroxide onto a gauze pad and begins swabbing the cut. They are silent for several seconds. Then:

direction.raw_text: So you're a lawyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. What are you doing in Bodega Bay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you practice here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, San Francisco. What are you...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What kind of law?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Criminal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that why you'd like to see everyone behind bars?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not everyone, Miss Daniels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only violators and practical jokers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right. As he swabs cut.

direction.raw_text: Ouch!

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. (pause) What are you doing up here?

direction.raw_text: Yes?

direction.raw_text: Yes.

There is nothing agrarian-looking about her. She speaks with the quick tempo of the city dweller, and there is lively inquiry in her eyes.

direction.raw_text: Certainly, but...

direction.raw_text: I'm sure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven o'clock then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: grinning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll be waiting. How's your head now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lydia looks at Mitch inquiringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's nothing, Mrs. Brenner. A gull hit me, that's all. Lydia stares at her doubtfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANNIE HAYWORTH'S HOUSE - FULL SHOT Melanie is standing on the front steps, a paper bag in her hands. She rings the doorbell. The ROOM TO LET sign is still in the window. The door suddenly opens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, hi! (pause) Did you find her all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I did. There is a long awkward pause. Annie smiles expectantly at Melanie. Melanie seems hesitant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was wondering...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That sign. (pause) Do you think I could have the room for a single night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'd really hope to rent it for...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would appreciate it. I've tried everywhere in town, and they're all full.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. You can have it. (smiles) Where's your bag? In the car? Melanie holds up the paper bag. Annie looks at it and then smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's utilitarian, I'll say that for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just picked up some things for the night at the general store. You see, I hadn't planned on spending much time here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I know. Did something unexpected crop up? There is a moment where both women look at each other... When Melanie answers, it is abrupt and a trifle cold -- she is again telling Annie to mind her own business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (pause) May I use your phone? I'd like to call home. There is another moment where Annie appraises Melanie's attitude, and then accepts it. She suddenly smiles warmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you come in then?  I was just about to mix a martini. She is about to lead Melanie into the house when they both hear a SOUND overhead. They turn to look skyward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: flying in beautiful precise formation against the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shaking her head) Don't they ever stop migrating? But Melanie is watching the sky and the birds with a curiously serious expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the Brenner house. Melanie's car is driving along the shore. Behind her, the sky is stained with sunset. There are gulls on the bay, cawing into the silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as it pulls into the Brenner yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reaching up for the rear view mirror, tilting it to examine her lipstick, touching the edge of her mouth with one hand. She gets out of the car, CAMERA FOLLOWING her to the house. She climbs the porch steps, KNOCKS on the door. There is no answer. Puzzled, she begins walking back into the yard. In the distance, she sees Mitch, Lydia and Cathy coming from behind the chicken sheds. She raises her arm in greeting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the distance. Mitch and Cathy raise their arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi! (she breaks into a trot toward Melanie)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as she approaches. She is an eleven-year- old child, clear-eyed, bright, uninhibited, wearing a shirt and blouse, her hair cropped close to her head. She hesitates for just a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Daniels?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes? And Cathy flings herself into Melanie's arms, almost knocking her off her feet, hugging her fiercely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're beautiful! They're just what I wanted! Is there a man and a woman? I can't tell which is which.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I suppose...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (coming up) Hi. Annie had no plans, huh? I'm glad you came. Are you hungry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Famished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dinner's just about ready. (explaining) We were out back looking at the chickens. Something seems to be wrong with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nothing wrong with those chickens, Mitch. I'm going to call Fred Brinkmeyer right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what good that'll do. (aside to Melanie) Chickens won't eat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as they ENTER, CAMERA FOLLOWING them throughout into dining room where Lydia dials phone, talking to Mitch all along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sold the feed to me, didn't he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Caviat emptor, Mother. Let the buyer beware.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whose side are you on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm simply quoting the law.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never mind the law. Cathy, you can start serving the soup. She has finished dialing now, is waiting while the phone RINGS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This won't take a minute, Miss Dan... (into phone) Hello, Fred? This is Lydia Brenner. I didn't interrupt your dinner, did I? (pause) Fred, that feed you sold me is no good. (pause) The chicken feed. The three bags I brought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: holding the telephone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's just no good. The chickens won't eat it. (pause) They're always hungry, Fred. I opened one of the sacks when I got home, and I poured it out for them, and they wouldn't touch it. Now you know chickens as well as I do, and when they won't eat, there's just something wrong with what they're being fed, that's all. (pause) No, they're not fussy chickens. (pause) Who? What's he got to do with it? (pause) Fred, I don't care how much feed you sold him. My chickens... (pause) He did? Dan Fawcett? (pause) This afternoon? (pause) Well, that only proves what I'm saying. The feed you sold us is... (pause) Oh. Oh, I see. Uh-huh. Uh-huh.  Uh- huh. Maybe I ought to go over to see him. You don't think there's something going around, do you? (pause) No, never. (pause) No, Fred, they don't seem sick at all. They just won't eat. (pause) Mmmm. Mmmmm. Well, I'll try to get over to Dan's farm.  Maybe he'll... mmmmm... mmmmm... all right, Fred, thanks. (she hangs up, puzzled)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Lydia comes to the table. Mitch and Melanie are sitting opposite each other in the center chairs. Cathy is serving the last bowl of soup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He got a call from Dan Fawcett a little while ago. His chickens won't eat, either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's what you said, Mom. Mr. Brinkmeyer's feed is no good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Cathy. He sold Mr. Fawcett a different brand. (extremely worried) You don't think they're getting sick, do you, Mitch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: her eyes troubled as she picks up her napkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The meal is over. The lovebirds in their hanging cage have been covered for the night. In the b.g. Mitch and Lydia are carrying the stacked dishes to the kitchen. In the f.g. Cathy and Melanie are by a small upright piano. Melanie is playing a Debussy Arabesque: She picks up a cigarette from the ashtray now and again to take a puff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I still don't understand how you knew I wanted lovebirds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your brother told me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you knew Mitch in San Francisco, is that right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not exactly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mitch knows lots of people in San Francisco. Of course, they're mostly hoods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cathy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Mom, he's the first to admit it. (to Melanie) He spends half his day in the detention cells at the Hall of Justice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a democracy, Cathy, everyone is entitled to a fair trial. Your brother's practice...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom, please, I know all the democracy jazz. They're still hoods. (to Melanie) He's got a client now who shot his wife in the head six times. Six times, can you imagine it? (she starts for living room) I mean, even twice would be overdoing it, don't you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did he shoot her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was watching a ball game on television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His wife changed the channel. He GOES INTO kitchen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mitch as he carries load of dishes out)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Melanie interrupts her playing to take another puff at her cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is smoking fun?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I suppose so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could I have a puff?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think your mother would like that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a little one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both glance conspiratorially toward the kitchen. Quickly, Melanie extends the cigarette. Quickly, Cathy takes a small puff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, it's just like air, isn't it? (determined) When I grow up, I'm gonna smoke like a chimney! I'll be eleven tomorrow, you know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you coming to my party?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so. (seeing the child's face) I have to get back to San Francisco.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you like us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Darling, of course I do!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you like Bodega Bay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mitch likes it very much. He comes up every weekend, you know, even though he has his own apartment in the city. He says San Francisco is just an ant hill at the foot of a bridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess it does get a little hectic at times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you do decide to come, don't say I told you about it. It's supposed to be a surprise party. Melanie laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, they've got this whole complicated thing figured out where I'm going over to Michele's for the afternoon, and Michele's mother is going to say she has a headache and would I mind very much if she took me home. Then, when we get back here, all of the kids'll jump out! (pause) Won't you come? Won't you please come?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: shaking her head, glancing toward the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so, Cathy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mitch is helping her as she loads the dishwasher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's a charming girl, isn't she, Mitch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, very.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And certainly pretty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long have you known her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you. We met yesterday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a bird shop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was selling birds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I only led her into believing I believed she was... Mother, it's really very complicated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But she did buy the lovebirds and then brought them all the way...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother, where did you go to law school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me. I suppose I'm just naturally curious about a girl like that. (pause) She's very rich, isn't she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suppose so. Her father owns a big newspaper in San Francisco.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd think he could manage to keep her name out of print. She's always mentioned in the columns, Mitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is the one who jumped into that fountain in Rome last summer, isn't she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps I'm old-fashioned. (pause) I know it was supposed to be very warm there, Mitch, but... well... actually... well, the newspaper said she was naked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know, Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's none of my business, of course, but when you bring a girl like that to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mother?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I can handle Melanie Daniels by myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... (she sighs) So long as you know what you want, Mitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know exactly what I want, Mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - EXTERIOR - NIGHT as Mitch and Melanie cross it to her car. A wind is blowing off the water, and high fast clouds are scudding across the face of the moon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be able to find your way back, won't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will I be seeing you again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: San Francisco's a long way from here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm in San Francisco five days a week. With a lot of time on my hands. I'd like to see you. (he grins) Maybe we could go swimming or something. Mother tells me you like to swim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How does Mother know what I like to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess she and I read the same gossip columns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. That. Rome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mmmm. I like to swim. We might get along very...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In case you're interested, I was pushed into that fountain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without any clothes on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With all my clothes on!  The newspaper that ran the story happens to be a rival of my father's paper.  Anything they said...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were just a poor, innocent victim of circumstance, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm neither poor nor innocent, but the truth of that particular...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truth is you were running around with a pretty wild crowd...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...who didn't much care for propriety or convention or...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...the opinions of others, and you went right along with them, isn't that the truth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, that's the truth. But I was pushed into that fountain, and that's the truth, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. Do you really know Annie Hayworth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. (pause) At least, I didn't until I came up here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you didn't go to school together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you didn't come up here to see her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were lying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I was lying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you really write a letter to me? Or was that a lie, too?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wrote the letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did it say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It said, "Dear Mr. Brenner, I think you need those lovebirds, after all. They may help your personality." That's what it said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you tore it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because it seemed stupid and foolish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like jumping into a fountain in Rome!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you what happened in Rome!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you expect me to believe...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't give a damn what you believe! Angrily she gets into the car, is about to slam the door when Mitch catches it in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd still like to see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it could be fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pulling the door shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That might have been good enough in Rome last summer. But it's not good enough now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But not for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (angrily sarcastic) I thought you knew! I want to go through life laughing and beautiful and jumping into fountains naked! Good night!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as it pulls away. Mitch yanks his hands back from the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he watches the car leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The car turns the bend and disappears. Empty road. Only the long line of telephone poles and wires and... something strange on the wires.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MITCH His attention caught by the poles and wires.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hundreds of birds sitting on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: standing and watching. A wind blows off the water. He shivers suddenly, turns up his collar, and heads for the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANNIE HAYWORTH'S LIVING ROOM - MED. SHOT - ANNIE HAYWORTH In an easy chair, reading. She is wearing a robe and smoking, absorbed in her book. She turns when she hears the front DOOR OPENING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Daniels? Is that you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Annie rises to greet her. As Melanie ENTERS THE SHOT:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi. (seeing her face) Is something wrong? Is that cut beginning to bother you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's not the cut that's bothering me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like some brandy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you have some, I'd...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get it, sit down, Miss Daniels. Do you want a sweater or something? A quilt? As Annie gets the brandy:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you. (pause) Won't you call me Melanie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right. (she smiles)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sitting, tucking her legs up under her. She is disturbed by her conversation with Mitch and, in fact, by the way this entire trip has worked out. Annie brings her the glass of brandy, and she takes it gratefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It gets a little chilly here at night sometimes. Especially if you're over near the bay. Melanie nods and sips at the brandy. There is a long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, how'd your evening go? Melanie shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you meet Lydia? Melanie nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or would you rather I changed the subject?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you like our little hamlet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I despise it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I don't suppose it offers much to the casual visitor. Unless you're thrilled by a collection of shacks on a hillside. It takes a while to get used to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you from originally, Annie?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: San Francisco.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How'd you happen to come here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, someone invited me up for the weekend a long time ago. There is an awkward pause. Annie shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I see no reason for being coy about this. It was Mitch Brenner. Melanie nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess you knew that, anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I suspected as much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You needn't worry. It's over and done with. A long time ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie -- there's nothing between Mitch and me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't there? (she shrugs) Maybe there isn't. Maybe there's never anything between Mitch and any girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I'll have some of that, too. (she pours brandy, drinks, sighs) I was seeing quite a lot of him in San Francisco, you know. (she smiles weakly) And then, one weekend, he asked me up to meet Lydia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When was this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four years ago. Of course, that was shortly after his father died.  Things may be different now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Different?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With Lydia. (pause) Did she seem a trifle distant?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A trifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then maybe it isn't different at all. You know, her attitude nearly drove me crazy. I simply couldn't understand it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I got back to San Francisco I spent days trying to figure out just what I'd done to displease her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what had you done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing! I simply existed. So what was the answer? A jealous woman, right? A clinging possessive mother. (she shakes her head) Wrong. With all due respect to Oedipus, I don't think that was the case at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what was it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lydia liked me, you see. That was the strange part of it. In fact, now that I'm no longer a threat, we're very good friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why did she object to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because she was afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Afraid you'd take Mitch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Afraid I'd give Mitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Afraid of any woman who'd give Mitch the only thing Lydia can give him -- love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie, that adds up to a jealous, possessive woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I don't think so. She's not afraid of losing her son, you see.  She's only afraid of being abandoned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Someone ought to tell her she'd be gaining a daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She already has a daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about Mitch? Didn't he have anything to say about this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can understand his position. He went through a lot with Lydia after his father died. He didn't want to risk going through it all over again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So it ended. Not immediately, of course. I went back to San Francisco, and I still saw Mitch every now and then... but we both knew it was finished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what are you doing here in Bodega Bay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You get straight to the point, don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. Forgive me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, that's all right, I don't mind. I came up here for two reasons. To begin with, I was bored with my job in San Francisco. I was teaching at a private school there... well, you know, you probably went to one yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you know. Little girls in brown beanies. Deadly. Here I have a life. I'll go into that classroom on Monday morning, and I'll look out at twenty- five upturned little faces, and each of them will be saying, 'Yes, please give me what you have.' (pause) And I'll give them what I have. I haven't got very much, but I'll give them every ounce of it. To me, that's very important. It makes me want to stay alive for a long long time. (she sighs) That's the first reason.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the second?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to be near Mitch. (pause) It was over, and I knew it, but I wanted to be near him, anyway. (she smiles) You see, I still like him a hell of a lot. That's rare, I think. I don't want to lose his friendship... ever. There is a moment of silence. Into the silence, the TELEPHONE shrills. Annie hesitates a moment, and then goes to answer it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: at the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?  Oh, hello. No, no, I wasn't asleep. What is it? (pause) Yes, just a little while ago. Sure, hold on. (she turns to Melanie) It's Mitch. For you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as they stare at each other across the room, Melanie hesitating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's waiting. Melanie rises and goes to the phone. The CAMERA FOLLOWS Annie to the wing chair in the foreground and stays on her throughout following, recording her reactions as Melanie talks to Mitch in the background. Annie is not devastated by this call, and yet there is a wistfulness to her expression as she realizes she may finally and irrevocably be losing Mitch to another girl.
direction.name: direction

(pause) No, I wouldn't want to disappoint Cathy, but... (pause) I see. (she is warming) I see. Well, if you really... (pause) All right. Yes, I'll be there. (pause) Good night, Mitch. direction.raw_text: Chee-chee-chee-chee-chee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leaving the cage. She walks to the sideboard upon which is an electric coffee percolator which is plugged into the wall. She feels it with her hand. It is hot. She pours a cup, then peers out of the side window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .O.V. Mitch on the shore, working with a rake in his hands. A thin column of smoke is climbing the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: carrying the cup of coffee. She sets it down for a moment to put on her fur coat, which is hanging on the hall stand. She picks up the cup again, walks to the front door and EXITS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: coming out of the house and into the garden, carrying the cup of coffee. It is a beautiful day. She sips at her coffee and then breathes deeply of the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fresh, rested. There is a contentment in her which we have not seen before. She looks off toward the shore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the shore, working with the rake. The thin column of smoke is climbing the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns her attention away from Mitch, and walks to the end of the garden toward the shore. A wind is blowing off the water, moving white puffs of cloud swiftly across the sky, whipping the full short shirt of muumuu about her legs as she walks. She stands there silhouetted against the sky for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Melanie scans the horizon. There isn't a bird anywhere in sight. The day is still and clear, but somehow ominous in its silence. Her gaze comes to rest on Mitch and the thin column of smoke again. In the distance, Mitch sees her and raises his arm in greeting. She waves back at him. He puts the rake down and begins walking toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is anticipation on her face now. She watches Mitch coming toward her, her eyes glowing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: closer to the house now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: waiting, anticipating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops, looks at her, and then turns toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as first surprised, and then puzzled. The back screen DOOR CLATTERS shut off screen. A small hurt look crosses her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as she turns away from the house and begins walking in the garden, sipping idly at her coffee. A screen DOOR CLATTERS again. She turns. Mitch is coming out of the house, from the front door, wearing a different shirt, buttoning it as he walks to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted to change my shirt. Melanie is uncomprehending.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It smelled of the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's hard to believe anything at all happened yesterday, isn't it? It's so beautiful and still now. (pause; then sagely) I think I've got it all figured out, by the way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? Tell me about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's an uprising.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of birds?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly, of birds. Mitch grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It all started several months ago with a peasant sparrow up in the hills, a malcontent. He went around telling all the other sparrows that human beings weren't fit to rule this planet, preaching wherever anyone would listen...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Growing a beard...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, of course, he had to have a beard! 'Birds of the world, unite!' he kept saying, over and over...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So they united.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at first. Oh yes, a few sparrows out for kicks...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, they'll go along with anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. But eventually, even the more serious-minded birds began to listen. "Why should humans rule?" they asked themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hear!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why should we submit ourselves to their domination?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hear, hear!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And all the while, that sparrow was getting in his little messages. Birds of the world, unite!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take wing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have nothing to lose but your feathers. They both burst out laughing, then fall into silence, then laugh again and finally are silent. The garden is deathly still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What it was, probably...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mmm?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're probably hungry, that's all. This was a bad summer. They eat berries and... and nuts, you know, and the hills are all burned out, so they're probably searching for food wherever they can get it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With my little sparrow leading team. She laughs, and Mitch joins her, but it is hollow this time. Like children who have told themselves a too realistic horror story, they are becoming a little frightened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's so damn quiet out there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was like that yesterday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After the gulls attacked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hadn't thought of that. (pause) And then the swifts came.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It makes you feel as if they're... they're waiting or... resting... or....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, they're having a meeting, Melanie. Your sparrow is standing on a soap box and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: her face dead serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...waving his little wings... His voice trails. His face becomes serious, too. Again, the garden is silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: her face set and grim, her eyes serious, her words coming slowly and with the chill of horror on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They were angry, Mitch. They came out of the chimney in fury. (pause) I had the feeling they wanted each and every one of us dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes her in his arms suddenly, to comfort her. She goes to him longingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melanie, Melanie...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm frightened, Mitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm frightened and confused and I... I think I want to go back to San Francisco where there are buildings and... and concrete and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melanie...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...everything I know. She looks up at him suddenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh damn it, why did you have to walk into that shop? They kiss suddenly and fiercely. On their kiss,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FAWCETT FARM - FULL SHOT - THE RED PICKUP TRUCK Lydia at the wheel, pulling into the Fawcett farm, the name of the farm clearly visible on a painted arch over the gate. Lydia gets out of the truck and walks to the front door. She knocks. There is no answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dan? She comes down off the steps, the CAMERA FOLLOWING, back a little away from the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dan? There is no answer. She shades her eyes and looks out over the fields.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THE BARNYARD as Lydia crosses to a fence and cups her hands to her mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hi, there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stops the tractor, turns toward Lydia, shading his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shouting) Is Mr. Fawcett home?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shouting back) I think so, ma'm. His missus is in Santa Cruz, but he ought to be here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you seen him this morning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, ma'm. I reckon he's in there, though.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shouting it) Thank you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as she crosses the barnyard again. There are several chickens scurrying about. She walks closer to them, sees an open bag of feed lying against the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: getting an idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reaching into the bag of feed. She scatters some on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, chick, chick, chick, chick. Here, chick, chick, chick, chick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He struts up to the scattered grain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He seems to be examining the feed. Then he turns away from it and struts off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a small knowledgeable nod of her head. The chicken's reaction strengthens her determination to talk to Fawcett.  She turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: approaching the front door again. She knocks. No answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dan? She backs away from the house again. The barnyard is silent. In the distance, we can HEAR the SOUND of the tractor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dan? Are you home? No answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a little annoyed. She glances at the ground floor window closest to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small pane of glass is broken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: going to the front door, trying the knob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door opening ahead of her as she pokes her head into the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dan? The house is still and silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Lydia comes in. We can see the living room off to the right, but it looks normal and untouched. Lydia turns to her left and looks down a long corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LYDIA'S P.O.V. a door at the end of it is partially ajar, spilling artificial light into the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dan? No answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a little troubled. She seems deciding whether or not she should leave. A determined look comes over her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LYDIA'S P.O.V. as she walks down it slowly toward the open door at the opposite end. Outside the door, she pauses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dan? Are you in there? No answer. Lydia puts out her hand, slowly begins showing the door open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: coming into the room. Her eyes begin to take in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LYDIA'S P.O.V. starting to the right of the doorway as she enters and continuing a little below eye level, the CAMERA PICKS OUT: A standing floor lamp, the shade dangling, but the light still burning; a picture hanging askew on the wall, its glass shattered; the window to the left of the picture, every pane of glass shattered; a dresser with two stuffed birds on its top; both birds have been badly damaged, the stuffing ripped out of them, the head of one hanging at a crooked near decapitated angle; the window to the left of the dresser, all the panes shattered. The level of the CAMERA DESCENDS, and begins a SLOW PAN of the floor. It PICKS OUT broken glass, continues its PAN to SHOW scattered feathers, continues its PAN to SHOW a broom, feathers caught in the straw, a single bedroom slipper, continues to SHOW a pair of legs in pajamas, one foot bare, the other slippered, and then immediately CUTS TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His face. Covered with blood, the eyes missing from their empty staring sockets.  Immediately
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a terrified scream erupting from her mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: turning and running for the door. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her in an unbroken headlong flight, the scream continuing as if she is incapable of stopping it, as she stumbles, runs, trips her way down the corridor and bursts out of the house, still screaming, into the pickup truck. The engine starts, she backs the truck out at breakneck speed and hits the highway,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  CLOSE SHOT - LYDIA at the wheel, her face stamped with terror, her eyes wide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: at breakneck speed, negotiating the severe curves on the highway. It almost hits a small car coming from the opposite direction, swerves, screeches around the curve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: behind the wheel, unmindful of anything but flight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LYDIA'S POV through the windshield, blurring past. She turns the bend leading to the house. For an instant, through the windshield, there is a quick glimpse of Melanie and Mitch in embrace in the garden. Then the tires shriek, and the truck turns and barrels into the front yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: alarmed as he runs out of the garden and toward the truck just as it jerks to a stop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: through the truck as he pulls open the door opposite Lydia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he sees his mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: slumped on the wheel of the car, her head on her arms, sobbing. On her sobs...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRENNER KITCHEN - MED. SHOT - MELANIE at the kitchen stove, taking a kettle of tea from the burner. She pours it into a cup, puts the cup on a tray already set with sugar and creamer. She looks up as Mitch comes into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was Al on the phone. He wants me to meet him out at the Fawcett place. Says some detectives from Santa Rosa'll be there in a little while. (pause) Will you be all right here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I was just taking her in some tea. He goes to her, puts his arms around her from behind, kisses her hair. But she turns in his arms suddenly and clings to him fiercely, and then buries her head in his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be careful. Please. She walks him to the door. At the door, they kiss -- a long, full kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- THE KITCHEN as Mitch goes out. Melanie looks after him for a moment, and then picks up the tray. Outside, we HEAR the SOUND of his car starting. The CAMERA FOLLOWS Melanie out of the kitchen, through the dining room, and to one of the bedroom doors on the other side of the house. Gently, she KNOCKS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mitch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is Lydia's room, and cluttered with the mementos of a life no longer valid.  There are photographs of her dead husband, souvenirs of trips taken together, bric-a-brac of Mitch's childhood. Under it all, there is a distinct femininity. She sits up in bed as Melanie enters, bearing the tray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's me, Mrs. Brenner. I thought you might like some tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thank you. There is a long silence as Melanie puts the tray on the bed, arranges the pillows behind Lydia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Mitch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Al Malone wanted him out at the Fawcett farm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why? Didn't Al believe my story?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was calling from the farm, Mrs. Brenner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then he saw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He must have. He sent for the Santa Rosa police.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What good will they do? She sips at the tea. There is a long awkward pause. Melanie walks to the window and looks out over the bay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think Cathy's all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cathy. At the school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: at the window, her face turned away from Lydia. Her expression clearly shows that she doesn't know whether Cathy is all right. But when she turns to Lydia, there is a comforting smile on her face, and her voice is soothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I'm sure she's fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I sound foolish to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I keep seeing Dan Fawcett's face. (she shudders) They have such big windows at the school. (pause) All the windows were broken. In Dan's bedroom. All the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try not to think of that, Mrs. Brenner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I were a stronger person. There is a long awkward silence. She sips at her tea reflectively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I lost my husband four years ago, you know. (pause) It's odd how you depend on someone for strength, and then suddenly all the strength is gone, and you're alone. (pause) I'd love to relax some time. I'd love to be able to sleep. (pause; the worried look again) Do you think Cathy's all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Annie's there. She'll be all right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not this way, you know. Not usually. I don't fuss and fret over my children. (pause) When Frank died... (pause) You see, he knew the children, he really knew them. He had the knack of being able to enter into their world, of becoming a part of them. That's a rare talent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I could be that way. There is another silence. A curious thing is happening in this room. Lydia, for perhaps the first time since her husband's death, is discussing it with another person. Curiously, the person is Melanie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I miss him. (pause) You know, sometimes I wake up in the morning, and I think 'I have to make Frank's breakfast,' and I... I get up and there's a... a very good reason for getting out of bed until... until, of course, I remember. (pause) I miss talking to him. (pause) Cathy's a child, you know, and Mitch... (she shrugs a little sadly) ...Mitch has his own life. (pause) I'm glad he stayed here today. I feel safer with him here. (she sighs deeply)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like to rest now, Mrs. Brenner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  No... don't go yet. (pause) I feel as if I... I don't understand you. And I want so much to understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, Mrs. Brenner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because my son is... (pause) My son seems to be fond of you. (pause) And I... (pause) I'm not quite sure how I feel about it. I really don't know if I... like you or not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that so important, Mrs. Brenner? You liking me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I think so. My son is important to me. I want to like any girl he chooses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if you don't?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I don't suppose it'll matter much to anyone but me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think it might also matter to Mitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mitch has always done exactly what he wanted to do. (pause) I'm not complaining. That's the mark of a man.  But... (pause) You see, I... I wouldn't want to be... be left alone. I don't think I could bear being left alone.  I... forgive me. This business with the birds has me upset.  I... I don't know what I'd do if Mitch weren't here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you try to sleep now, Mrs. Brenner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I were stronger. (she pauses and looks toward the window.) Do you think she's all right? Do you think she's safe at the school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you like me to go for her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't ask you to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't mind, really.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you? I'd feel so much better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll just clear up here, and then dress. She picks up the tray and starts for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melanie? At the door, Melanie turns.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (going to the bed; adjusting the pillow)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: her face soft.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you for the tea.
direction.name: direction

Melanie is puffing away at her cigarette and occasionally glances in the direction of the school. We hold on this shot of Melanie for a very long time so that we are able to express her ignorance of what is going on behind her with the crows. After a wait of about what seems to be a half a minute or more, Melanie's attention is drawn to something above her.

direction.raw_text: Crow moving down and LEFT to RIGHT, the sky and Annie's roof in the background.

direction.raw_text: UP - MELANIE Her head has twisted around to follow the flight of the crow. She is almost looking into the play yard.

direction.raw_text: A crow slowly descends to the play yard and as the CAMERA FOLLOWS it down, we see for the first time that the number of crows has increased to an alarming number - almost 200 or even perhaps 250. This last crow settles down with the others.

direction.raw_text: I asked my wife to wash the floor. Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, mo, mo, mo! She gave me my hat and showed me the door! Ristle-tee, rostle-tee, hey bombosity, knickety-knackety, Retro-quo-quality, (the song slows -- it is near the end) Willoby-wallaby, mmmmmmmo, mmmmmmmoo, Mo!

direction.raw_text: The play yard is full of crows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Big head of horrified Melanie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A closer view of the menacing birds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Big profile of Melanie. She turns with back to CAMERA and goes toward school looking at crows as she goes away. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her for a few paces and then STOPS so that her image becomes smaller as she goes up steps into

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Melanie in headlong flight toward Annie's room.

direction.raw_text: All right, children. Now please put your books in your desks, and bring the songsheets to the front of the room. No one's going out to play until I have all the songsheets.

direction.raw_text: Annie is lining the children up near the door leading to the play yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not going outside until we quiet down. Ralph? Did you hear me? The children mutter for a moment, and then are still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right now. She begins opening the play yard door. Suddenly, the door from the corridor bursts open, and Melanie rushes wildly INTO the room. She goes directly to Annie, shoves her out of the way, and SLAMS shut the play yard door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: against a background of children's VOICES, as they react to this new excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THROUGH THE WINDOWS TWO SHOT - ANNIE AND MELANIE MELANIE We've got to get the children out of here. These big windows... there's no way to board them up. Annie gives a quick nod, understanding immediately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the windows, we can see the waiting crows. One moves restlessly into flight, then settles on the equipment again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quiet down, children! Quiet down! The children modulate into silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Daniels wants to see how we conduct ourselves during a fire drill. I'd like you to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fire drill? This is our play period, Miss Hayworth! Gee whiz!  Etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like you to show her how quiet and obedient you can be. The children again fall silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to go out of the school now. Those of you who live nearby can go directly home. I want the rest of you to go down the hill, all the way to the hotel. Do you understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the way down the hill? Gee, Miss Hayworth, we never... Home? Why do we...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to go as quietly as you can, not a sound, until I tell you to run. And then I want you to run as fast as you can. Does everyone understand? (pause - silence) All right. John, would you lead the class, please? The children walk two-by-two to the corridor door. John opens it, and they begin filing out. Melanie turns to look at the play yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: fluttering at the window, almost in exploration. He hangs there for a moment, then wings back to the playground equipment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (whispering) Hurry!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: straight on of all the crows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but a different angle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but a different angle from the others
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (12) A low angle of five or six crows filling the screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The screen is filled with crows. About fifty or more. All of a sudden we HEAR the distant PATTERING of children's feet as they start running. Immediately the crows rise and the CAMERA PANS UP with them into the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (PLATE) (15) The FULL SHOT showing the children running toward the CAMERA - Annie herding them at the rear. The crows - about two hundred - rising over the schoolhouse roof and descending toward and reaching the running children. Shot as a moving background with six or seven children in front on a treadmill with the mechanical birds coming into top of screen as though continuing on from the plate. The birds swing around and among the foreground children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) A side view of running children with Melanie in front urging them forward. Birds fly between them, two or three others wheel around, one live one sweeps by in foreground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (P) Three or four children running. Birds overhead - one or two children spread out as others come in from sides and take their places. Birds swerve in and out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) Profile of running child. Bird catches up and bites.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) A nearer side on view without Melanie. Birds wheeling in and out - others overhead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (P) Bird on top of girl's head (showing feet and wings).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) A three-quarter back of two children running - lots of birds overhead and others wheeling. Screen almost full of birds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (P) One-half child's face - a bird's head and beak on left, dashing round to the child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP (L) of feet running.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (L) showing the crows among the running children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (P) Big head of girl - bird lands on her right shoulder - wing over her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (P) One SCREAMING child as bird swoops from top left down to lower right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) Head and shoulders of boy who ducks behind pole -- bird goes by as another attacks him from right-hand side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (FP) Back view of boy's head running. He looks back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (P) Big head of bird coming at CAMERA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (FP) Back view of little girl running. She looks over her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (P) Big head of bird coming into CAMERA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (L) Straight back CLOSE SHOT of Annie dragging slow children. No birds in back, but several wheeling around them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (L) showing the crows chasing the children down the street - with the Bay in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) A bird dives to head of Michele and she falls OUT of picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP (1) (L) of Michele as she hits ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: UP (12) (L) Her glasses smash.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) Flash Cathy - she sees and runs back. Birds swirling around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) Six birds descend on fallen Michele - legs running by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) Cathy RUSHES IN. She disperses birds and bends to pick up Michele.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) Melanie stops, looks back and sees Cathy and Michele, heads of other children rushing by in foreground. Birds swirling. Melanie dashes out left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) Melanie reaches Cathy and Michele -- Michele is now on her feet. Birds swirling -- Melanie looks about -- sees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (L) Station wagon across the street. Birds swirling about and children running by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (L) Melanie drags Cathy and Michele to the station wagon. We see the Bay in the distance and children running on the bottom of the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (S) Shooting inside the wagon across the front seat. The three scramble in, Cathy first, then Michele and Melanie last -- the door SLAMS on crows swooping around. Cathy and Michele are SCREAMING with fright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (FP) Through the windshield we see crows attacking. Bay and running children in distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (P) The faces of the three - Birds are fluttering on the rear window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (P) wheel in foreground. She starts to slam hand on horn ring.
